Name: n-Pentadecane
Description: Pentadecane is a straight-chain alkane with 15 carbon atoms. It is a component of volatile oils isolated from plants species like Scandix balansae. It has a role as an animal metabolite, a plant metabolite and a volatile oil component.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Serrazanetti GP et al; Chemosphere 23: 925-38 (1991) (2) Serrazanetti GP et al; Chemosphere 28: 1119-126 (1994)
plant_concentrations.Value: The concentration of n-pentadecane in plankton collected from the North Central Adriatic Sea was determined to range from 0.7-11.1% in the spring and 0.8-12.0% in the summer(1). Samples collected between December 1990 and August 1991 from the Gulf of Trieste contained n-pentadecane ranging in concentration from traces to 0.8%(2).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) USDA; Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases. Plants with a chosen chemical. Pentadecane. Washington, DC: US Dept Agric, Agric Res Service. Available from, as of Nov 13, 2015: https://www.ars-grin.gov/duke/
plant_concentrations.Value: n-Pentadecane was detected in the Myrtus communis (Myrtle, Myrtaceae) plant at a concentration of 2 ppm. It was detected, not quantified in the following plants(1):

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Carril Gonzalez-Barros ST et al; Chemosphere 36: 597-602 (1998) (2) Taylor DL et al; Marine Poll Bull 20: 465-68 (1989)
animal_concentrations.Value: The concentration of n-pentadecane in tissue samples collected from 12 wolves of Northern Spain /Canis lupus signatus/ was determined to be 2.24, 2.08 and 1.65 mg/kg lipid weight in suprarenal capsules, muscle, and spleens, respectively(1). The concentration of n-pentadecane in blubber collected from walruses (Odobenus rosmarus divergens) in six locations of the Pacific Ocean was determined to range from 0 to 0.03 ppm wet weight(2).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Al-Saad HT; Marine Pollut Bull 21: 155-57 (1990) (2) Hesselberg RJ, Seelye JG; Identification of Organic Compounds in Great Lakes Fishes by Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry: 1977. Admen Rep No 82-1. Ann Arbor,MI: US Fish Wildlife Soc Great Lakes Fishery Lab (1982) (3) Pena E et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 57: 803-10 (1996) (4) Peterman PH, Delfino JJ; Biomed Environ Mass Spec 19: 755-70 (1990) (5) Quintero S, Diaz C; Marine Pollut Bull 28: 44-49 (1994) (6) Snedaker SC et al; Marine Poll Bull 31: 83-89 (1995) (7) Walsh K et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 28: 35-39 (1995) (8) Welch KJ et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 26: 724-28 (1981)(9) Winger PV et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 19: 101-17 (1990)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Thirteen species of fish collected from the Arabian Gulf during 1985 were found to contain n-pentadecane concentrations in muscle ranging from 0.4 to 1.9 ug/g dry weight(1). n-Pentadecane was found in samples of adult lake trout (Salvelinus namaycush) and walleye (Stizostedion v. vitreum) collected in 1977 from Lake Michigan, Lake Huron and Lake Superior, quantity unknown(2). n-Pentadecane concentrations identified in specimens of the marine winkle Osilimus attratus collected off the coast of Tenerife, near northern Africa, ranged from 289.9 to 675.7 ng/g(3). n-Pentadecane was identified but not quantified in carp collected from the Upper Fox River, WI(4). The concentration of n-pentadecane identified in the fish species Boops boops, Scomber japonicus, and Sardina pilchardus collected near the Canary Islands was determined to be 594, 1216, and 5503 ng/g wet weight, respectively(5). The concentration of n-pentadecane in fish collected in the Florida Keys from 1990-1992 was determined to range from 10 to 248 ug/kg dry weight, depending upon species(6). n-Pentadecane was detected in the tissue of the mollusk Austrocochlea constricta, collected along the coast of Australia, ranging in concentration from 1.30 to 1.35 ug/g dry weight(7). In an eight-year study conducted, n-pentadecane was detected in fish collected from Eastern Montana rivers with concentrations ranging from 0.1 to 42.5 ug/g dry weight(8). The mean concentration of n-pentadecane in channel catfish, bowfin, white catfish, fiddler crab, and sea catfish collected from the Savannah River, Georgia/South Carolina between February 1984 and August 1985 was determined to range from 0.02 to 0.76 ug/g wet weight(9).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Akiyama T et al; J UOEH 2: 285-300 (1980) (2) de Leeuw et al; Anal Chem 58: 1852-57 (1986) (3) Hamilton SE et al; Environ Sci Technol 18: 72-79 (1984) (4) MacLeod WD Jr et al; Symp Fate Effects Petroleum Hydrocarbons on Marine Ecosystems and Organisms pp. 385-96 (1977) (5) Snedaker SC et al; Marine Poll Bull 31: 83-89 (1995) (6) Bixiong Y et al; Chemosphere 68: 140-194 (2007) (7) Doskey PV; Environ Sci Technol 35: 247-254 (2001) (8) Hori T et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 83: 455-461 (2009)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: In the heavily industrialized area of Kitakyushu, Japan, n-pentadecane was detected but not quantified in sediment(1). The concentration of n-pentadecane in sediment samples collected in the northwestern part of the Netherlands was determined to be 300 ppm(2). n-Pentadecane was identified as a component of suspended matter and sediments of the Green-Duwamish River, Washington in a study conducted from 1978-1981(3). n-Pentadecane was identified in sediment from Port Angeles harbor, WA, an area contaminated with fuel oil and in Dungeness Bay, a nearby relatively pristine area, concentration unspecified(4). The concentration of n-pentadecane in surface sediments collected in the Florida Keys from 1990-1992 was determined to range from 21 to 403 ug/kg dry weight(5). n-Pentadecane was detected in sediment samples collected from three rivers and six canals in Tianjin, China in July 2002(6). n-Pentadecane was detected in sediment samples collected from various sites in Lake Michigan(7). Surface sediments collected from the Shinano River in Niigata, Japan between November 2005 and April 2006 contained n-pentadecane concentrations of 3.3 to 25 ng/g dry weight(8).
